awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Informed and Ecological Decision Making of COVID-19 Vaccination
awd_abstract_narration:
Vaccination is the most effective method to prevent infectious diseases like coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and prompt herd immunity. However,  herd immunity could be slowed or stalled if people hesitated to be vaccinated. This project aims to facilitate informed vaccination decisions. The research aims to illuminate how people’s vaccination decisions evolve in response to their social context. The project’s novelty is to follow participants over time to evaluate their real-world decision making about vaccination. The project will advance the state-of-the-art on risk communication during crises and decision-making under uncertainty. The project will identify effective communication about COVID-19 vaccines that are understandable by, and applicable to, the public. The project could ultimately improve the immunization rate of the population to pass the threshold for herd immunity and the collective health benefits of immunization. 

The project entails four tasks that will advance the understanding of human vaccination decision-making under risk and uncertainty. (1 ) Develop communications about the COVID-19 vaccines that are experimentally varied in completeness, transparency, and correctness by leveraging the standards of risk communication in the health domain.  (2) Evaluate the effectiveness of proposed communications in enhancing people’s knowledge of COVID-19 vaccines and informing their vaccination decisions.  (3) Examine the effectiveness of proposed communications on informing peoples’ vaccination decisions in real-world application settings. (4) Investigate how people respond to uncertainties of different situations in order to understand how vaccination decisions evolve throughout the current vaccination campaign.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Evidence-based information on the benefits and risks of vaccines is necessary for informed vaccination decision-making. Leveraging the standards of good risk communication, we proposed evidence-based, transparent (benefits and risks) communication of COVID-19 vaccines. With the emerging variants of SARS-CoV-2, we further explore factors that are critical for human’s acceptance of a booster does of COVID-19 vaccines. The online studies with representative samples showed that transparent and evidence-based communication can be effective in mitigating people’s vaccine hesitancy.  Moreover, such communication can increase people’s COVID-19 (continuous) vaccination intention and confidence.  Such communication was even more effective for the unvaccinated group compared to the vaccinated group. Evidence-based communication was effective in helping people comprehend the safety of COVID-19 vaccines. 

A few works have further investigated human’s trust in XAI for misinformation mitigation (e.g., Seo et la., 2019; Epstein et al., 2022). In agreement with prior work, our current study replicated previous findings in a novel context (i.e., COVID-19 misinformation). Moreover, we identified other critical factors of XAI (e.g., the framing effect and the impact of system reliability) for human misinformation detection and mitigation. In general, this line of work is one of the pioneering studies in the space of XAI for misinformation detection and mitigation, which has the potential to inspire new research directions in the community. 

We have also explored the COVID-19 misinformation in deepfake contexts. This is one of the first works to caution against the impact of deepfake in the downstream tasks, which could guide the design and training of human deepfake detection and mitigation. 

During the COVID-19 pandemic, the pandemic tracking app has been shown as a valuable tool to understand how humans perceive and manage privacy and utility in the context of sensitive personal data.  Moreover, individuals have diverse values and varied privacy preferences.  With directly interacting with the users, our study revealed the dynamics of user privacy preferences when deploying privacy-enhancing technologies, which can be used to enhance the state-of-the-art technical solutions (e.g., sampling and scaling mechanism for individualized DP). 

We train graduate students (two female) to work in interdisciplinary teams and conduct research in information science.
